sentence: Consumer goods maker Procter & Gamble ( PG ) is a true dividend aristocrat, with a 60-year streak of dividend increases.
Expect the company to extend its impressive streak this week when it announces its next distribution.
The stock has gained 6.1% on the year.
PG was recently trading at $89.37, down $2.63 from its 12-month high and $10.27 above its 12-month low.
Overall technical indicators for PG are bullish with a strong upward trend.
The stock has recent support above $88.00, and resistance below $91.90.
Of the 15 analysts who cover the stock, five rate it a "strong buy", one rates it a "buy", and nine rate it a "hold".
The stock receives S&P Capital IQ's 5 STARS "Strong Buy" ranking.
With such an impressive streak of dividend increases, there is little doubt that Procter & Gamble will make another increase this year.
The stock has a payout ratio of 69.4%, so investors should not be expecting a huge increase.
Last year the company boosted its quarterly distribution by just 0.9%, and I would look for a similar increase this year given the current payout ratio.
Look for the quarterly distribution to rise from $0.669 to around $0.675, for an increase of 0.9%.
The company will likely announce the increase this week, with the stock trading ex-dividend about a week after the announcement.
If you want a bullish hedged trade on the stock, consider a July 80/82.50 bull-put credit spread for a 20-cent credit.
That's a potential 8.7% return (30.2% annualized*) and the stock would have to fall 7.5% to cause a problem.
If you want to take a bearish stance on the stock at this time, consider a July 95/100 bear-call credit spread for a 20-cent credit.
That's a potential 4.2% return (14.5% annualized*) and the stock would have to rise 6.5% to cause a problem.
